Peripheral Blood Smear Morphology:  Erythrocytes are normocytic and normochromic without significant poikilocytosis.  Leukocytes are adequate in number and morphologically normal.  Platelets are adequate in number and morphologically normal.

Bone Marrow Aspirate Morphology:  Adequate for evaluation; spicules present.  Trilineage hematopoiesis present; M:E ratio =     .  Myeloid and erythroid precursors are morphologically normal without evidence of dyspoiesis.  Megakaryocytes are adequate in number and morphologically normal.  No abnormal cell populations are identified.

Bone Marrow Core Biopsy & Particle Clot Morphology:  Both are adequate for evaluation with trilineage hematopoiesis and      cellularity.  Myeloid and erythroid precursors are reasonably distributed and no abnormal proliferative or infiltrative processes are identified.

The biopsy consists of cervical mucosa, with a mixture of squamous and columnar epithelium.  Multiple sections reveal no significant atypia.  The cells show good maturation, and diagnostic dysplasia is not noted.
Multiple fragments of endocervical tissue are present.  Most of these are mucosa only, but some stroma is also evident.  The cells show a uniform columnar appearance without dysplasia.

The tissue contains breast tissue with some areas of epithelial and stromal proliferation.  The epithelium is in the form of multiple thin ductules.  These are surrounded by, and frequently compressed by a proliferation of cellular stroma.  There is a suggestion of mucinous change in the stroma in some areas.  No atypia is present.
The biopsy shows breast tissue with fibrocystic changes including non-atypical hyperplasia. Calcifications are present.

The tissue consists of mostly fibrous connective tissue with some fatty tissue also present.  A sclerotic cyst wall is present, lined by cells consistent with synovium.  Mild fibrosis and chronic inflammation are present in the surrounding connective tissue.  In addition, there is a suggestion of mucin deposition within the connective tissue focally.

Multiple portions of endometrium are present with a variety of appearance.  Foci of glandular and stromal breakdown are present.  In these areas, there is separation of the glands from the surrounding stroma with curling up of the stroma into small balls.  A mixture of inflammatory cells is present in these areas, and there is a suggestion of fibrin deposited within the stroma as well.  No hyperplasia or atypia are seen.

Multiple fragments of fibrous tissue and frayed cartilaginous material are present.  The latter contain numerous chondrocytes, some single, and some in small clusters.  A few fragments of bone are also present.  No inflammation is seen.

The tissue consists of mature appearing fat which is well-circumscribed, suggesting a delicate capsule around the surface.  The cells are somewhat variable in size and shape, but the nuclei are small and benign appearing.  No nuclear atypia is seen.

The tissue consists of mostly fibrous connective tissue.  Areas of mild sclerosis are present.  In one area, a thickened nerve is present, with some mild sclerosis of the perineurium.  No significant inflammation is present.

The tissue contains numerous breast ducts in a fibrous tissue background.  The ducts are mildly dilated, and display a uniform, mild hyperplasia without atypia.  There is mild to moderate periductal edema.  No carcinoma is seen.

A cyst is present, composed of benign squamous epithelium.  This shows abrupt keratinization with some areas of relatively solid keratin.  A granular layer is not prominent in the epithelium.  There is no dysplasia noted.
The pleural fluid shows benign mesothelial cells with scattered lymphocytes. No atypia is identified.

A few sheets of small, benign cells are present.  These suggest mesothelial cells, being polygonal and flat.  The nuclei are small and uniform.  Scattered lymphocytes are present, along with small fragments of connective tissue.  No carcinoma is identified.

The placental substance is composed of mature-appearing villi.  These are small and well vascularized.  Hydropic change is not noted.  Only small amounts of fibrin are present, and there is no hypercellularity or villitis seen.  Both the fetal surface of the disc as well as the membranes have a normal appearance with no unusual inflammatory infiltrate.  A focus of infarct appears bland with no inflammation visible.  Sections of the umbilical cord contain the usual three vessels.  No inflammation is identified.

The placenta is composed of mature villi.  These have good vascularity, and no hydropic change.  Acute inflammation is present beneath the fetal surface of the placenta.  This is seen as a band of neutrophils infiltrating the tissue.  Similar acute inflammation is present in the membranes.  No villitis is evident.  Sections of the umbilical cord contain the usual three vessels.  Acute inflammation is present surrounding the vessels as well.

The material contains numerous immature chorionic villi.  These show relatively poor vascularity.  Some of them are edematous, but diagnostic hydropic change is not present.  In addition, portions of inflamed decidua are present.  These are infiltrated by acute and chronic inflammatory cells, and appear focally necrotic.  No fetal parts are evident.

Multiple portions of decidua are present, consisting of stroma with large polygonal cells.  Heavy inflammation is present in some areas, with a mixture of acute and chronic inflammatory cells.  No fetal parts or chorionic villi are identified.

The endometrium has a ___ appearance.  No hyperplasia or atypia are evident.  The myometrium appears normal, with no evidence of adenomyosis.  The serosal is unremarkable.  Scattered inflammation is present in the endocervix, but no acute inflammation or dysplasia.

Inflammation is present, along with some fibrosis.  Most of the inflammation is in the form of lymphocytes, and no acute inflammation is seen.  Fibroblasts are also present between the bony spicules.  Some cells contain hemosiderin pigment.  There is no carcinoma identified.

The tissue consists of a small muscular artery.  The wall is of normal thickness, and the lumen likewise appears normal.  No inflammatory cell infiltrate is seen.  In particular, no giant cells are evident.  A special stain for elastic demonstrates normal inner and outer laminae.
Microscopic examination is performed and supports the above diagnosis.

Excessively long umbilical cords (>70 cm) have been associated with increased risk of nuchal cord, umbilical cord prolapse, increased fetal nucleated red blood cells, chorangiosis, fetal vascular thrombi, and meconium-stained membranes.
Ref: Pediatr Dev Pathol. 2001 Mar-Apr; 4(2): 144-53.

Single umbilical artery is an uncommon cord abnormality associated with congenital anomalies (particularly affecting the cardiac and renal systems), increased perinatal mortality, prematurity, and low birth weight.  Refs: Genet Med 2004 Jan-Feb; 6(1): 54-7.  Perspect Pediatr Pathol. 1984 Winter; 8(4): 345-78.
Early funisitis in the absence of other histologic features of ascending amniotic fluid infection may be seen with intermittent umbilical cord compression.

Clinicopathologic correlation with length of umbilical cord left on the baby and any used for blood gas analysis is recommended to evaluate overall cord length.  Short umbilical cords (variably defined as 35 to 40 cm) have been associated with decreased fetal movement in utero (as may be seen with amniotic bands, oligohydramnios, body wall defects, and fetal neuromuscular disorders, among others), low Apgar scores, small size for gestational age, and psychomotor abnormalities.  Refs: Obstet Gynecol. 2004 Jan; 103 (1): 119-27.  J Pediatr. 1985 Aug; 107 (2): 278-81.  Obstet Gynecol. 1981 Apr; 57 (4): 450-2.

Microscopic examination reveals small bowel mucosa with intact villous architecture and increased epithelial lymphocytes (greater than 35 lymphocytes per 100 enterocytes).

Epithelial lymphocytosis (greater than 35 intraepithelial lymphocytes per 100 enterocytes) is observed in the absence of significant villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia and mononuclear cell expansion of the lamina propria.  Although lymphocytic duodenosis is often a nonspecific finding, it may be seen in gluten-sensitive enteropathy (corresponding to a Marsh type 1 lesion).  It is also seen in peptic injury, NSAID use, and viral gastroenteritis, among others.  Correlation with clinical, endoscopic and serologic findings is necessary for definitive characterization.

The histologic features are consistent with (ascending amniotic fluid infection / placental abruption / preeclampsia).

In some instances, chronic villitis is associated with congenital infections by the following organisms:  Toxoplasma gondii, Rubella virus, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes Simplex Virus (TORCH infections), Parvovirus, Treponema pallidum, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Histoplasma, Varicella Zoster Virus, and Enteroviruses.  In cases in which an infectious cause cannot be demonstrated, the possibility of a maternally-derived immune reaction against the placenta has been postulated.  Clinicopathologic correlation and serum antibody titers are recommended if clinically indicated.  Ref:  Am J Pathol. 1993 Aug; 143(2): 473-9.

Increased fetal nucleated red blood cells may be associated with congenital anemia due to a variety of etiologies including congenital infection, fetal maternal hemorrhage, congenital anomalies, blood group incompatibility, Rh disease, and placental abruption, among others.  Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.  Ref:  Arch Dis Child Fetal Neonatal Ed. 2001 May; 84(3): F211-5.

Maternal diabetes has been associated with placental abnormalities including placentomegaly, chorangiosis, villous immaturity, and villous edema.  Cord abnormalities such as increased cord diameter and single umbilical artery have also been noted.  Ref:  Placenta. 2003 Sep-Oct; 24(8-9): 819-25.
Septic intervillous thrombi and/or acute villitis have been associated with in utero infections with organisms such as Listeria monocytogenes, among others.  Ref:  NEJM 1997; 336(20): 1439-46.

Gross and histologic features of a small, growth-restricted placenta, accelerated villous maturation, infarcts, and decidual vasculopathy (acute atherosis) are characteristic of preeclampsia.  Refs:  Indian J Pathol Microbiol. 1990 Jan; 33(1): 11-6. Obstet Gynecol. 1964 Sep; 24: 350-6.

Gross and histologic features of a small, growth-restricted placenta, accelerated villous maturation, infarcts, and decidual vasculopathy are characteristic of low uteroplacental perfusion.  Conditions associated with low uteroplacental blood flow include lack of physiologic conversion of spiral arteries, uterine artery thrombosis, gestational hypertension, systemic lupus erythematosus, thrombotic syndromes, and preeclampsia, among others.  Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.
The fetal inflammatory response exceeds the maternal inflammatory response, a situation that is commonly encountered in beta-Streptococcal infections, among others.

Early funisitis, in the absence of other histologic features of ascending amniotic fluid infection (e.g. acute chorioamnionitis, chorionic vasculitis, etc.) may be seen with intermittent umbilical cord compression.

Fetal vascular obstruction (fetal artery thrombosis, hemorrhagic endovasculitis, intimal cushion defects, fetal stem villous thrombi) has been associated with maternal diabetes, maternal thrombophilia, chorioamnionitis, and umbilical cord abnormalities.  When extensive, fetal vascular obstruction has been associated with fetal growth restriction, neurologic impairment (including cerebral palsy), vascular compromise, and stillbirth.  Refs:  Hum Pathol. 1999 Jul; 30(7): 759-69.

Multiple intervillous thrombi suggest the possibility of fetomaternal hemorrhage and have been associated with fetal anemia, fetal thrombocytopenia, and maternal sensitization.  A Kleihauer-Betke test is recommended if clinically indicated.  Ref:  J Obstet Gynaecol Br Commonw. 1964 Jun; 71: 379-87.
Pigmented macrophages within the extraplacental membranes and/or Wharton's jelly are associated with meconium exposure.

Microscopic examination of the cellular enhancement preparation reveals scattered urothelial cells arranged singly and in small clusters.  The cells contain ample cytoplasm and small round to ovoid nuclei.  There is no evidence of high grade dysplasia/malignancy.

Intestinal spirochetosis represents colonization of the colon by usually nonpathogenic spirochetes (Brachyspira aalborgi and Serpulina pilosicoli) and may be associated with chronic diarrhea.  It may also be found in up to 10% of normal patients.  If the patient is symptomatic, metronidazole is the recommended therapy for this condition.

Microscopic examination reveals sections of umbilical cord, extraplacental membranes, and placental disc.  The umbilical cord contains three vessels and is free of acute inflammation or other pathologic abnormality.  The extraplacental membranes are likewise free of inflammation; the attached decidua displays no evidence of decidual vasculopathy.  Pigmented macrophages are not identified.  Sections of placental disc show appropriately mature villi with scattered microcalcifications.  Increased villous cellularity/vascularity, villous edema, and nucleated red blood cells within the villous capillaries are not identified.  The intervillous space is free of inflammation or marked perivillous fibrin deposition.  Infarcts are absent.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

Gastric mucosal calcinosis (GMC) is an unusual finding and may be metastatic, dystrophic, or idiopathic in nature.  Metastatic calcinosis arises in the setting of altered serum electrolytes (i.e. hyperphosphatemia, hypercalcemia), usually resulting from end stage kidney disease, primary hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, metastatic malignancy, hypervitaminosis D, or tumor lysis syndrome.  Dystrophic calcification typically arises in the setting of tissue damage (i.e. inflammation, fibrosis, trauma) and may be seen in association with gastric ulcers, reactive gastropathy, and gastritis, among others.  GMC is also associated with the consumption of aluminum-containing antacids and sucralfate.  Clinical correlation is recommended.

The histologic differential diagnosis includes an eczematous process (such as allergic contact dermatitis or atopic dermatitis), drug eruption, and arthropod assault.  Clinical correlation is necessary.

A very small cluster of atypical acini is noted in close approximation with high grade PIN.  Immunohistochemical staining results are inconclusive in determining whether these acini represent invasive carcinoma or budding high grade PIN.  Because a significant number of patients with atypical small acinar proliferations are found to have invasive carcinoma on subsequent biopsies, close clinical follow-up with repeat biopsy is recommended.

The histologic features are highly suspicious for Helicobacter pylori-associated gastritis despite the absence of organisms on immunohistochemical stain.  Because detection of Helicobacter organisms can be influenced by factors such as bacterial load, patchy anatomic distribution and proton pump inhibitor use, correlation with additional clinical studies (e.g. H. pylori stool antigen) is recommended.

Though normal lamina propria eosinophil counts can vary widely among individuals and are poorly defined in the medical literature, eosinophils appear increased for anatomic location.  The histologic differential diagnosis includes allergic enteritis/colitis, early/evolving inflammatory bowel disease (in which diagnostic histomorphologic findings have yet to develop), drug reaction, and systemic vasculitides, among others.  Parasites are not identified.  Recommend correlation with clinical presentation and laboratory studies (e.g. peripheral eosinophil count, food allergy testing, etc.).

Causes of acute erosive gastritis include drug/NSAID-related injury, excessive alcohol use, heavy smoking, bile reflux, uremia, severe stress, ischemia, and mechanical trauma, among others.  Recommend clinical and endoscopic correlation.

Ganglion cells are not identified on ??? H&E-stained levels.  Several studies have demonstrated loss of reactivity for calretinin in tissues procured from patients with Hirschsprung's Disease.  Calretinin immunohistochemical stain has also shown similar sensitivity and specificity compared to acetylcholinesterase stain when used as an adjunct in diagnosis.  The biopsy material represented in specimen ??? shows lack of calretinin staining in lamina propria and submucosal nerve fibers.  Assuming that these biopsies were obtained at least 2 cm above the pectinate line, these findings support a diagnosis of Hirschsprung's Disease in the appropriate clinical setting.

Chronic intervillositis is associated with pregnancy-induced hypertension, connective tissue diseases (e.g. lupus erythematosus), maternal drug use, diabetes, low birth weight, poor fetal outcome and recurrent fetal loss.  Ref:  Doss BJ, Greene MF, Hill J et al.  Massive chronic intervillositis associated with recurrent abortions.  Hum Pathol 1995; 26: 1245-51.

In general, thrombocytopenia is caused by: 1) decreased platelet production, as seen in hematopoietic malignancies or bone marrow suppression related to certain drugs; 2) increased platelet destruction, as seen in idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura; 3) increased sequestration, such as in hypersplenism; and 4) platelet dilution, as seen in hemorrhage or with multiple blood transfusions.  Recommend clinical correlation and additional evaluation, as indicated.

Erythrocytosis may be primary (polycythemia rubra vera) or secondary in nature.  Secondary erythrocytosis can be caused by hypoxic disorders (pulmonary disease, smoking, cardiovascular shunt, high altitude) and non-hypoxic disorders (paraneoplastic syndrome, nonneoplastic renal disease).  To differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia, clinical correlation and additional evaluation (e.g. erythropoietin level, JAK2 mutation analysis) are recommended.

Normocytic anemia may be seen with acute hemorrhage, chronic hemolytic disorders, anemia of chronic disease, renal insufficiency, and in chronic inflammatory conditions.  Recommend clinical correlation and further evaluation, as indicated.

Leukopenia may be seen with certain drugs, infections (especially viral), myelophthisis, nutritional deficiencies, hypersplenism, alcoholism, and cachexia. Though intestinal metaplasia is not identified, focal multilayered epithelium is noted. Recommend clinical follow up.
